references: Fitch, H. S. 1970. Reproductive cycles of lizards and snakes. Univ. Kansas Museum Natural History Miscellaneous Publication 52:1-247.
Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
Collins, J. T. 1990. Standard common and current scientific names for North American amphibians and reptiles. SSAR Herpetol. Circular No. 19. 41 pp.
Conant, R. and J. T. Collins. 1991. A field guide to reptiles and amphibians:eastern and central North America. Third edition. Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, Massachusetts. 450 pp.
Conant, R. 1975. A Field Guide to Reptiles and Amphibians of Eastern and Central North America. Second Edition. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. xvii + 429 pp.
Collins, J. T. 1991. Viewpoint:a new taxonomic arrangement for some North American amphibians and reptiles. SSAR Herpetol. Review 22:42-43.
Gibbons, J. W., J. W. Coker, and T. M. Murphy, Jr. 1977. Selected aspects of the life history of the rainbow snake (FARANCIA ERYTROGRAMMA). Herpetologica 33:276-281.
Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
Tennant, A. 1997. A field guide to snakes of Florida. Gulf Publishing Company, Houston, Texas.  257 pp.
Dundee, H. A., and D. A. Rossman. 1989. The amphibians and reptiles of Louisiana. Louisiana State Univ. Press, Baton Rouge.
Dowling, H. G. 1993. Viewpoint:a reply to Collins (1991, 1992). Herpetol. Rev. 24:11-13.
Ernst, C. H., and R. W. Barbour. 1989. Snakes of eastern North America. George Mason Univ. Press, Fairfax, Virginia. 282 pp.
Palmer, W. M., and A. L. Braswell. 1995. Reptiles of North Carolina. North Carolina State Museum of Natural Sciences, University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina.
NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
Mitchell, J. C. 1994. The reptiles of Virginia. Washington, DC: Smithsonian Institution Press.
Mount, R. H. 1975. The Reptiles and Amphibians of Alabama. Auburn University Agricultural Experiment Station, Auburn, Alabama. vii + 347 pp.
Ernst, C. H., and E. M. Ernst. 2003. Snakes of the United States and Canada. Smithsonian Books, Washington, D.C.
Mitchell, J. C. 1982. Farancia erytrogramma. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 293.1-293.2.
habitat_description:
This species is found west of the Mississippi River along the Coastal Plain from southern Maryland to Florida (Conant and Collins 1991; Dundee and Rossman 1989; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Tennant 1997).

This species burrows in or using soil, leaf litter, fallen logs, among cypress roots, wet debris, and mats of vegetation nearby water bodies. The rainbow snake is found in association to creeks, and low gradient medium sized rivers, but primarily characterized by shallow water. The more terrestrial associations occur in forested and herbaceous wetlands. Its habitat includes swamps, springs, open marshes, and brackish tidal areas. Hibernaculum also takes place in uplands near water (Dundee and Rossman 1989; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Mount 1975; Palmer and Braswell 1995).

SE	-Cover includes soil, leaf litter, decaying logs, wet debris, and mats of vegetation nearby water bodies.
